description: From Middle English transporten, a borrowing from Old French transporter (“carry or convey across”), from Latin trānsportō, from trans (“across”) + porto (“to carry”).

examples: The transport of goods is not included in the price given on the website.

entries.meaning: The state of being transported by emotion; rapture.
examples: In her transport at finding such treasures, Heidi even forgot Peter and his goats.

entries.meaning: A vehicle used to transport (passengers, mail, freight, troops etc.)
The system of transporting passengers, etc. in a particular region; the vehicles used in such a system.
examples: The local transport received a big boost as part of the mayor's infrastructural plans.

entries.meaning: A device that moves recording tape across the read/write heads of a tape recorder or video recorder etc.

verbs.description: transport (third-person singular simple present transports, present participle transporting, simple past and past participle transported)

entries.meaning: To carry or bear from one place to another; to remove; to convey.
examples: to transport goods; to transport troops

entries.meaning: (historical) To deport to a penal colony.
(figuratively) To move (someone) to strong emotion; to carry away.
